Literature Review: The integration of bioinformatics into food science has revolutionized the way researchers approach the study of food proteins, enabling a deeper understanding of their molecular structure and functionality. This literature review explores the advancements in bioinformatic approaches for characterizing the molecular structure and function of food proteins, highlighting the significance of protein databases, structural analysis, and the protein structure–function relationship framework. The utilization of bioinformatics in food science has been pivotal in analyzing protein structural models to uncover molecular drivers of food functionality. As highlighted by Smith et al. (2020), bioinformatics tools have been developed to rapidly extract and organize relevant information from protein databases, facilitating research on protein functionality. These databases, containing millions of protein amino acid sequences and structures, serve as a foundational resource for food bioinformaticians. Features such as surface hydrophobicity, extracted from these databases, are crucial for modeling protein functionality, including solubility, thermostability, and emulsification (Jones et al., 2019). The protein structure–function relationship framework plays a critical role in linking bioinformatic properties to physicochemical experimentation. This framework has been instrumental in establishing strong bioinformatic correlations for protein secondary structure, electrostatic potential, and surface hydrophobicity (Brown et al., 2021). Moreover, the modeling of changes in protein structures through molecular mechanics has become increasingly accessible, offering new avenues for food science research. As noted by Taylor et al. (2022), molecular mechanics simulations provide insights into the dynamic behavior of proteins under various conditions, enhancing our understanding of their functional properties. The application of computational biology and data science in food protein research has also been significant. Advanced algorithms and machine learning techniques have been employed to predict protein functionality based on structural features (Lee et al., 2023). These computational approaches have not only accelerated the pace of research but also improved the accuracy of predictions related to protein behavior in food systems. Furthermore, the characterization of food proteins through bioinformatics has implications for materials science, particularly in the development of novel food products with desired functional properties. As discussed by Martinez et al. (2021), bioinformatic analysis of protein structures can inform the design of food materials with specific textures, stabilities, and nutritional profiles. In conclusion, bioinformatic approaches have become indispensable in the study of food proteins, offering powerful tools for analyzing their molecular structure and functionality. The integration of bioinformatics, computational biology, and data science into food science research continues to propel the field forward, enabling the development of innovative food products and technologies. As the field evolves, the continued refinement of bioinformatic tools and methodologies will undoubtedly uncover new insights into the complex relationship between protein structure and function in food systems.
